Welcome to EncryptedDB's documentation!¶

Modules and functions¶

This module is considered the application interface with the user.

main.create_keys() → None¶

This function replaces the old RSA keys with new ones, for security or maintenance reasons. This function must be run when starting the application for the first time (no RSA parameters have been created before in this case) or if any external changes have occurred to the files which store them (the files being located in the Keys directory).

main.create_workspace() → None¶

This function (re)creates the application's table inside database. Using this function is recommended when targeting to clean the table's records and (re)create the FILES as an empty table.

main.crypto(private_key: int) → str¶

This function captures the interaction between the user and the application. This might be considered the top layer which encapsulates accessing the database, parsing the user's commands and responding to them and all the cryptographic operations performed in the layers below.

Parameters:

private_key ((int, int, int)) -- the private (fixed) key derived from computing rsa parameters; keys can be changed from this module as well, so their 'time to leave' is decided by the user

main.display_menu() → None¶

This function displays the possible commands a user can issue and their corresponding formatting rules. The commands' menu is printed on screen every time the user has to input a new command. This way all the rules he has to follow are displayed right in front of him at the time he needs to compose his command.

main.extract_keys() -> (<class 'int'>, <class 'int'>, <class 'int'>)¶

This function aims to extract the RSA keys from the local files where they are stored. The keys are stored in hexadecimal format. When extracted, they are also converted to big integers. If the user decides so, keys can be (re)generated, which causes the corresponding files to be overwritten.

Returns:

the RSA private key

Return type:

(int, int, int)

This module performs AES-128 symmetric encryption. Plaintext, ciphertext and keys are considered to be in hexadecimal

aes128.add_one(counter: str) → str¶

This function performs adding one operation.

Parameters:

counter (str) -- the counter used by the CTR iteration mode

Returns:

counter + 1 (in hexa)

Return type:

str

aes128.add_round_key(state_matrix: list[list[str]], key: str) → list[list[str]]¶

The addition of round constants.

Parameters:

  • state_matrix (list[list[str]]) -- the block's state matrix

  • key (str) -- the round key

Returns:

the new state of the block matrix

Return type:

list[list[str]]

aes128.apply_decryption_round_transformation(state_matrix: list[list[str]], key: str, round_no: int) → list[list[str]]¶

The customized succession of operations for decryption. Encryption operations are performed in reverse order (first comes the addition of round constants etc.)

Parameters:

  • state_matrix (list[list[str]]) -- the state matrix of the block being decrypted

  • key (str) -- the round key

  • round_no (int) -- the round's index

Returns:

the new state of the block matrix after performing the required operations

Return type:

list[list[str]]

aes128.apply_main_transformations(plaintext_block: str, round_keys: list[str], original_block: str, mode: str = 'encrypt') → str¶

Applies the transformation per 128-bits (or less) block, known as: substitution bytes, shift rows, mix columns and addition of round constants. There are 10 rounds, preceded by an initial addition of round constant. The last round lacks the mix columns operation.

Parameters:

  • plaintext_block (str) -- the target block (derived from the counter)

  • round_keys (list[str]) -- the round keys previously returned by the key scheduling algorithm

  • original_block (str) -- the initial text (provided that CTR operation mode is used)

  • mode (str) -- indicates whether transformations are performed during encryption or decryption. It has 2 possible values, namely encrypt and decrypt, first one being the default value

Returns:

the encrypted/decrypted block

Return type:

str

aes128.apply_round_transformation(state_matrix: list[list[str]], key: str, round_no: int) → list[list[str]]¶

This function performs the round transformations on specified block. The block is kept as 4x4 state matrix. The same matrix is changed during each round.

Parameters:

  • state_matrix (list[list[str]]) -- the state matrix

  • key (str) -- the round key

  • round_no (int) -- the index of the round

Returns:

the new state of the block matrix

Return type:

list[list[str]]

aes128.compute_round_key(ante_key: str, key_round: int) → str¶

Computes one round key. There are 10 rounds in the key scheduling algorithm and this function contains repetitive steps that apply for each of them.

Parameters:

  • ante_key (str) -- the key generated at the previous round (round 0 is the base round)

  • key_round (int) -- the index of the current round

Returns:

the generated round key

Return type:

str

aes128.convert_text_into_matrix(block: str) → list[list[str]]¶

Hexadecimal string is converted into 4x4 matrix. The matrix takes two hexa units for each of its elements.

Parameters:

block (str) -- the 32 hexadecimal units block

Returns:

the (transposed) matrix derived from the block

Return type:

list[list[str]]

aes128.decrypt_aes128(counter: str, ciphertext: str, key: str) → str¶
This function performs AES-128 decryption in CTR mode. The operations being performed are:

  • key generation

  • key scheduling => round keys

  • counter(s) generation

  • encrypting counters in AES-128 CBC mode for single words

  • xoring counters with the blocks of ciphertext provided through parameter

Parameters:

  • key (str) -- the symmetric key generated at encryption

  • counter (str) -- the counter as starting point for CTR encryption

  • ciphertext (str) -- encrypted data

Returns:

original data

Return type:

str

aes128.divide_ciphertext(ciphertext: str) → None¶

Plaintext is divided into blocks of 128 bits each. Last block might contain less than 128 bits.

Parameters:

ciphertext (str) -- the encrypted message (which is about to be decrypted)

aes128.divide_plaintext(plaintext: str) → None¶

Plaintext is divided into blocks of 128 bits each. Last block might contain less than 128 bits.

Parameters:

plaintext (str) -- the original message (the one which is being symmetrically encrypted)

aes128.encrypt_aes128(plaintext: str) -> (<class 'str'>, <class 'str'>, <class 'str'>)¶
This function performs AES-128 encryption in CTR mode. The operations being performed are:

  • key generation

  • key scheduling => round keys

  • counter(s) generation

  • encrypting counters in AES-128 CBC mode for single words

  • xoring counters with the original blocks of plaintext

Parameters:

plaintext (str) -- the data to be encrypted

Returns:

encrypted data

Return type:

(str, str, str)

aes128.generate_128bits_random() → str¶

Exactly 128-bits random generation.

Returns:

exactly 128-bits random, converted into hexa string

Return type:

str

aes128.get_ciphertext(transposed_final_matrix: list[list[str]]) → str¶

AES 4x4 matrix is converted back to hexadecimal string.

Parameters:

transposed_final_matrix (list[list[str]]) -- the matrix to be converted

Returns:

the (transposed) matrix as hexadecimal string

Return type:

str

aes128.key_schedule(key: str) → list[str]¶

Implementation of the key scheduling algorithm from the AES-128 standard.

Parameters:

key (str) -- the base key

Returns:

all 11 round keys, the first one being the base key

Return type:

list[str]

aes128.mix_columns(state_matrix: list[list[str]], mode: str = 'standard') → list[list[str]]¶

The addition of round constants.

Parameters:

  • state_matrix (list[list[str]]) -- the block's state matrix

  • mode (str) -- standard or inverse (every word but standard will be perceived as inverse) The fixed matrix required at this step, which is constant, depends on the operation performed (encryption or decryption)

Returns:

the new state of the block matrix

Return type:

list[list[str]]

aes128.multiply_by_02(x: str) → str¶

Special multiplication by 02 in GF(pow(2, 8)) function. The input and output are still hexa strings.

Parameters:

x (str) -- the number aimed to be multiplied by 02

Returns:

the result of the multiplication operation

Return type:

str

aes128.multiply_matrices(static_m: list[list[str]], dynamic_m: list[list[str]]) → list[list[str]]¶

Multiplication of hexa matrices required at the mix columns operation.

Parameters:

  • static_m (list[list[str]]) -- the fixed matrix

  • dynamic_m (list[list[str]]) -- the state matrix

Returns:

the result matrix

Return type:

list[list[str]]

aes128.multiply_stream(y: str, x: str) → str¶

This function is built with the purpose of multiplying two hexa strings.

Parameters:

  • x (str) -- the first hexa string

  • y (str) -- the second hexa string It only takes values from {01, 02, 03, 09, 0B, 0D, 0E}, due to the structure of the fixed matrix used at the mix columns operation

Returns:

the result as hexa string

Return type:

str

aes128.pad_with_zeros(block: str) → str¶

This function aims to add additional zeros to the blocks which are less than 128 bits in length. Due to the fact that blocks are encoded in base16, the required length becomes 32 hexadecimal units.

Parameters:

block (str) -- the block to be padded

Returns:

the padded block

Return type:

str

aes128.parallelize_ctr(counters: list[str], round_keys: list[str], mode: str = 'encrypt') → str¶

This function implements the CTR mode for a set of counters through parallelization of the encryption required for each of them.

Parameters:

  • counters (list[str]) -- the counters corresponding to each plaintext block in CTR mode

  • round_keys (list[str]) -- round keys for encrypting counters

  • mode (str) -- encrypt or decrypt depending on the operation performed on the text blocks

Returns:

the ciphertext of the specified block in CTR mode

Return type:

str

aes128.s_box_transformation(pair: (<class 'str'>, <class 'str'>), mode: str = 'standard') → str¶

The s-box atomic substitution.

Parameters:

  • pair ((str, str)) -- a pair of two hexa units identifying the row and column in the (inverse) s-box matrix

  • mode (str) -- standard or inverse (every word but standard will be perceived as inverse) The mode corresponds to the operation performed (encryption or decryption)

Returns:

the element located at the intersection of row pair[0] and column pair[1]

Return type:

str

aes128.shift_rows(state_matrix: list[list[str]], shift_per_column: list[int]) → list[list[str]]¶

The rows shifting operation. Rows are left shifted with number of elements provided by shift_per_column depending on the row index.

Parameters:

  • state_matrix (list[list[str]]) -- the block's state matrix

  • shift_per_column (list[int]) -- the number of elements which have to be shifted for each row (index)

Returns:

the new state of the block matrix

Return type:

list[list[str]]

aes128.substitution_bytes(state_matrix: list[list[str]], mode: str) → list[list[str]]¶

The bytes substitution operation. The hexadecimal units are replaced with combinations provided by the special s-box matrix.

Parameters:

  • state_matrix (list[list[str]]) -- the block's state matrix

  • mode (str) -- standard or inverse (every word but standard will be perceived as inverse) There are different s-box matrices depending on the nature of the operation (encryption or decryption)

Returns:

the new state of the block matrix

Return type:

list[list[str]]

aes128.xor_matrix(text: list[list[str]], key: list[list[str]]) → list[list[str]]¶

This function is built with the purpose of xoring two 4x4 hexa matrices.

Parameters:

  • text (list[list[str]]) -- the first matrix

  • key (list[list[str]]) -- the second matrix

Returns:

the result as 4x4 hexa matrix

Return type:

list[list[str]]

aes128.xor_stream(key: str, rcon: str) → str¶

This function is built with the purpose of xoring two hexa strings.

Parameters:

  • key (str) -- the first hexa string

  • rcon (str) -- the second hexa string

Returns:

the result as hexa string

Return type:

str

This module works with integers and implements the RSA-OAEP scheme. OAEP is the padding method being used.

rsa_oaep.compute_parameters() -> ((<class 'int'>, <class 'int'>, <class 'int'>), (<class 'int'>, <class 'int'>))¶

This function uses lower layers such as rsa_generator and miller_rabin in order to generate large RSA keys. The size of p and q is established inside this function, so is e from the public key. There is a code block which enforces that e and (p-1), (q-1) are relatively prime to each other.

Returns:

the pair consisting of one public and one private generated key

Return type:

((int, int, int), (int, int))

rsa_oaep.decrypt_rsa(ciphertext: int, private_key: (<class 'int'>, <class 'int'>)) → int¶

Implements the classic RSA decryption step, by raising the ciphertext (as integer) to the power of d from the private key. It is known that d from private key is the modular inverse of e from public key (modulo (p-1) * (q-1), which makes d hard to guess), making the whole process result into the initial plaintext.

Parameters:

  • ciphertext (str) -- the encrypted information which is to be decrypted

  • private_key ((int, int, int)) -- the private key which serves for decryption

Returns:

initial data being decrypted

Return type:

int

rsa_oaep.decrypt_rsa_oaep(ciphertext: int, private_key: (<class 'int'>, <class 'int'>, <class 'int'>), expected_len: int) → int¶

Implementation of the RSA-OAEP decryption step. First RSA decryption on the ciphertext is performed, followed by OAEP decoding.

Parameters:

  • ciphertext (int) -- the encrypted information which is to be decrypted

  • private_key ((int, int, int)) -- the private key which serves for decryption

  • expected_len -- the expected length of the result (this influences the internal

transformations made by the algorithm and, therefore, the overall result) :type expected_len: int :return: initial data being decrypted :rtype: int

rsa_oaep.encrypt_rsa(plaintext: int) → int¶

Implements the classic RSA encryption step, by raising the plaintext (as integer) to the power of e from the public key.

Parameters:

plaintext (int) -- the information to be encrypted

Returns:

the result of the encryption operation described above as an exponentiation

Return type:

int

rsa_oaep.encrypt_rsa_oaep(plaintext: int) → int¶

Implementation of the RSA-OAEP encryption step. First OAEP padding is performed, followed by RSA encryption on the padded plaintext.

Parameters:

plaintext (int) -- the information to be encrypted

Returns:

the result of the encryption operation described above

Return type:

int

rsa_oaep.oaep_padding_decode(cipher: int, message_len: int, zeros: int, rand_bits: int) → int¶

Implementation of the encoding step of the OAEP padding scheme. Some additional information such as the initial message's length is required.

Parameters:

  • cipher (int) -- the data being subject to decoding

  • message_len (int) -- the length of the initial message (the one which was encoded)

  • zeros (int) -- the number of zero bits which were added at the end of the initial message during encoding (established by the protocol)

  • rand_bits (int) -- the number of random bits contained by the seed (established by the protocol)

Returns:

not anymore padded message

Return type:

int

rsa_oaep.oaep_padding_encode(message: int, zeros: int, rand_bits: int) -> (<class 'int'>, <class 'int'>)¶

Implementation of the encoding step of the OAEP padding scheme. The message is randomized before encryption in order to force the encryption method not to be deterministic.

Parameters:

  • message (int) -- the message to be padded (before encryption)

  • zeros (int) -- the number of zero bits being added at the end of message

  • rand_bits -- the number of random bits contained by the seed

Type:

int

Returns:

the padded version of the message, consisting of two bit subsequences, which are individually converted to integers

Return type:

(int, int)

This module generates rsa primes.

rsa_generator.gen_rsa_prime_parameters(size: int) -> (<class 'int'>, <class 'int'>)¶

Generates rsa prime parameters widely known as p and q, of size given as parameter. p and q are prime numbers tested 10 times against the Miller-Rabin test.

Parameters:

size (int) -- the desired length (same length, in bits) of p and q

Returns:

p and q

Return type:

(int, int)

rsa_generator.generate_prime(size: int) → int¶
Generates prime number of exactly size bits. The primality is checked using the Miler-Rabin probabilistic

primality test.

Parameters:

size (int) -- the size of the prime which is about to be generated (in bits)

Returns:

the first generated prime number which passed the primality test

Return type:

int

This module contains some success/error messages for the situations which were identified as possible and frequent usability routines, depending on the user's inputs.

sha256.add_length() → None¶

This function replaces the last 64 bytes of the plaintext with the length of the initial message in binary form.

sha256.add_one() → None¶

This function adds a bit set on 1 at the end of the message/plaintext.

sha256.addition(bytes1: str, bytes2: str) → str¶

This function performs addition between two octet strings. The octet strings are firstly converted to integers, so that modulo pow(2, 32) addition can be performed.

Parameters:

  • bytes1 (str) -- the first octet bit

  • bytes2 (str) -- the second octet bit

Returns:

the result of the addition operation

Return type:

str

sha256.and_operation(bytes1: str, bytes2: str) → str¶

This function performs and operation between two octet strings. The octet strings are firstly converted to integers and additional bytes are added if necessary to obtain a complete 32-bit block.

Parameters:

  • bytes1 (str) -- the first octet bit

  • bytes2 (str) -- the second octet bit

Returns:

the result as octet string

Return type:

str

sha256.apply_main_block_transformation(plain_block: str) → None¶

This function iterates through all the steps required for binary blocks in order to update hashes at the end of each round of transformations per block. Essentially, the so-mentioned transformations involve performing message scheduling and compression. Plaintext is split into 16 32-bit blocks, which are added 48 brand new 32-bit on 0 blocks. For each 32-bit block, compression is performed.

Parameters:

plain_block (str) -- the binary string block to perform transformations on

sha256.apply_main_transformations() → None¶

This function iterates through the 512-bit blocks and updates the hashes. Eventually, it computes the digest after the last block has passed through all the required transformations.

sha256.compression(bytes32: str, counter: int, copy_hashes: list[str]) → list[str]¶

The compression function mixes the hashes from the previous round of transformations per block by performing right rotations, &-operations, not-operations, switching and additions on them. The 32-bit plaintext block prove their utility during additions.

Parameters:

  • bytes32 (str) -- the current 32-bit block

  • counter (int) -- the index of the block

  • copy_hashes (list[str]) -- the current version of the hashes

Returns:

the updated version of the hashes

Return type:

list[str]

sha256.compute_digest(particular_hashes: list[str]) → str¶

This function joins all hashes into an octet string.

Parameters:

particular_hashes (list[str]) -- the final version of the hashes

Returns:

the digest derived from concatenating all the hashes (which are, in fact, octet strings)

Return type:

str

sha256.convert_hashes_to_binary() → None¶

This function converts integers to octet strings. The target integers are the hashes required by the digest computing algorithm.

sha256.create_hashes() → list[str]¶

This function ensures that, at the beginning of each round of transformations per block, the operations start with the updated version of the hashes, which was obtained during the computations made for the previous message block. :return: the last version of the hashes list :rtype: list[str]

sha256.create_message_schedule(bytes_array32: list[str]) → list[str]¶

This function updates the last 48 32-bit blocks of the plaintext by combining right rotations, right shifts and additions on the previous blocks.

Parameters:

bytes_array32 (list[str]) -- the plaintext split into 32-bit blocks

Returns:

the updated plaintext as an 32-bit octet strings list

Return type:

list[str]

sha256.execute_sha256(user_plaintext: str) → str¶

This function concatenates all the necessary steps for computing sha-256 binary digest. Details about pre-processing, 512-bit and 32-bit (atomic) block transformations are listed inside the description of the corresponding functions.

Parameters:

user_plaintext (str) -- the plaintext on which digest is aimed to be computed

Returns:

the hash digest

Return type:

str

sha256.initialize_sha256() → None¶
This function initializes the hashes list which will be used during sha-256

digest computing and converts all 8 of them to binary format.

sha256.modify_hashes_within_chunk_loop(particular_hashes: list[str]) → None¶

This function performs addition between the last version of the hashes (last updated at the end of the previous round of transformations per block) and the last version of the particularly updated hashes during the transformations performed on the current block.

Parameters:

particular_hashes (list[str]) -- the last version of the hashes (last updated at the end of the previous round of transformations per block)

sha256.not_operation(bytes_only: str) → str¶

This function operates on a bit block and negates it, by reversing all its bits. More precisely, the length stays the same, all the 0's become 1's and all the 1's become 0's.

Parameters:

bytes_only (str) -- the bit block to perform negation on

Returns:

the negated bit block

Return type:

str

sha256.padding_until_512_less64() → None¶

This function pads the plaintext with 0’s until data is a multiple of 512, less 64 bits (448 bits).

sha256.pre_processing() → None¶

This function encapsulates the pre-processing operations performed on the plaintext before actually computing the hash digest: adding a one bit, padding with 0's and adding the length at the end.

sha256.right_rotate(text: str, bits: int) → str¶

This function moves to the end a couple of bits located at the beginning of the octet string.

Parameters:

  • text (str) -- the octet string on which the rotation is performed

  • bits (int) -- the number of bits being moved

Returns:

the updated octet string

Return type:

str

sha256.right_shift(text: str, bits: int) → str¶

This function performs right-shifting with a number of bits on text.

Parameters:

  • text (str) -- the octet string on which the shifting is performed

  • bits (int) -- the number of bits being shifted

Returns:

the updated octet string

Return type:

str

sha256.split_plaintext_into_blocks() → None¶

This function splits the plaintext into 512-bits blocks. The blocks are encoded as octet strings.

sha256.xor(bytes1: str, bytes2: str) → str¶

This function performs xor (particular binary addition) between two octet strings.

Parameters:

  • bytes1 (str) -- the first octet bit to be xored

  • bytes2 (str) -- the second octet bit to be xored

Returns:

the result of the xor operation

Return type:

str

# This module works with binary representations of numbers and outputs masks of given size starting from given seed.

mgf1.mgf(mask_length: int, seed: int) → str¶

This is a mask generation function (mgf) based on sha-256 hash function. Essentially, the seed is given to the hash function. This operation repeats multiple times, while a counter is increasing at every step in order to be concatenated to the seed before hashing. It is well known that slightly different messages usually produce totally different hashes, so the counter is used to randomize the seed.

Parameters:

  • mask_length (int) -- the desired length of the mask (usually the mask is going to be xored with some other cryptographic input, so the two must be equally large)

  • seed (int) -- random number given to the hash function

Returns:

generated mask of exactly mask_length bits, starting from given seed, as octet string

Return type:

str

Raises:

TypeError -- when the seed is not of integer type

commands.connect_to_database() → Connection¶

This function facilitates connecting the application module to the database in order to perform insertions, retrievals and deletions.

Returns:

the connection being opened

Return type:

pyodbc.Connection

commands.create_files_table() → None¶

This function (re)creates the FILES table in order to keep metadata and cryptographic information about the target files.

commands.delete_file(name: str = '', path: str = '') → str¶

This is where the delete command is being executed.

Parameters:

  • name (str) -- the name of the target file

  • path (str) -- the path where the target file is located

Returns:

success or error message, depending on the use-cases encountered

Return type:

str

Raises:

AttributeError -- if none of the 2 possible identifiers of the file has been specified by the user or if targeted file does not exist within the database (and neither do its identifiers)

commands.get_metadata(file_path: str) -> (<class 'str'>, <class 'str'>, <class 'int'>, <class 'bool'>, <class 'bool'>, <class 'int'>, <class 'int'>, <class 'str'>, <class 'bool'>)¶

This function gathers metadata about the file located at file_path.

Parameters:

file_path (str) -- the path of the target file

Returns:

the essential metadata of the target file

Return type:

(str, str, int, bool, bool, int, int, str, bool)

commands.insert_all_data(name: str, file_path: str, encrypted_key: str, metadata: (<class 'str'>, <class 'str'>, <class 'int'>, <class 'bool'>, <class 'bool'>, <class 'int'>, <class 'int'>, <class 'str'>, <class 'bool'>)) → None¶

This is where the database operations regarding the upload command are performed.

Parameters:

  • name (str) -- the unique identifier wished by the user

  • file_path (str) -- the path to the target file

  • encrypted_key (str) -- the RSA-encrypted symmetric key used for file encryption

  • metadata ((str, str, int, bool, bool, int, int, str, bool)) -- metadata about the target file; includes: absolute path, base file name, size, if read operations are permitted, if write operations are permitted, owner id, group id, hash digest of the file, if the file has been deleted from disk (but the encryption is kept),

commands.insert_encrypted_file(file_path: str, name: str) → str¶

This is where the upload command is being executed. The file located at file_path, along with its metadata, is inserted into the database and will be further identified under name. Multiple file formats have been treated (.txt, .docx, .pdf).

Parameters:

  • file_path (str) -- the path to the target file

  • name (str) -- the file identifier

Returns:

success or error message, depending on the use-cases encountered

Return type:

str

commands.retrieve_decrypted_file(private_key: (<class 'int'>, <class 'int'>, <class 'int'>), name: str = '', path: str = '') → str¶

This is where the read command is being executed. The content of the target file is displayed to the user. The content of the file is decrypted using the asymmetric key stored within the database. Multiple file formats have been treated (.txt, .docx, .pdf).

Parameters:

  • private_key ((int, int, int)) -- the private RSA key for decrypting the asymmetric key stored within the FILES table

  • name (str) -- the unique identifier of the target file (optional)

  • path (str) -- the path to the target file (optional)

Returns:

the content of the target file (as plaintext) or an error message if exceptions have occurred at the retrieval operation

Return type:

str

Raises:

AttributeError -- if none of the 2 possible identifiers of the file has been specified by the user

commands.retrieve_from_database(name: str, path: str) -> (<class 'str'>, <class 'str'>, <class 'int'>)¶

This is where the database operations regarding the read command are performed.

Parameters:

  • name (str) -- the name of the target file

  • path (str) -- the path where the target file is located

Returns:

the name, path (updated if not specified from the very beginning) and the encrypted symmetric key which was used at file encryption

Return type:

(str, str, int)

Raises:

AttributeError -- if targeted file does not exist within the database (and neither do its identifiers)

commands.solve_command(request_code: int, params: list[str], private_key: (<class 'int'>, <class 'int'>, <class 'int'>)) → str¶

This function implements command solving as far as user's inputs are concerned. After passing through a pre-processing step and acquiring the green flag for validation, the command is split into a request code and its actual parameters (tags for identifying parameters such as -n or -p are eliminated during pre-processing the input). The request code corresponds to one of the following operations: 0 ~ upload; 1 ~ read; 2 ~ delete; 3 ~ exit.

Parameters:

  • request_code (int) -- an integer (from [0-3]) identifying the requested operation

  • params (list[str]) -- the actual parameters of the request, regarding the file (name and path)

  • private_key ((int, int, int)) -- the private RSA key serving for decryption of the symmetric key used in AES-128

Returns:

the result of the operation (file content or specific messages)

Return type:

str

This module validates commands and separates them into request and request parameters starting from the user keyboard input.

command_parser.delete_retrieve_validate(params: list[str]) -> (<class 'bool'>, list[str])¶

Validates the read/delete parameters issued by user in the second part of his query. At least one of name and path must be specified. The user can specify both but in this case only name will be taken into account.

Parameters:

params (list[str]) -- the raw parameter string issued by the user

Returns:

the validation tuple made up of the OK code and the actual parameters' list

Return type:

(bool, list[str])

command_parser.exit_validate(params: list[str]) -> (<class 'bool'>, list[str])¶

Validates the exit command which should consist of a single word and no parameters.

Parameters:

params (list[str]) -- the raw parameter string issued by the user

Returns:

the validation tuple made up of the OK code and the actual parameters' list

Return type:

(bool, list[str])

command_parser.parse(command: str) -> (<class 'bool'>, <class 'int'>, list[str])¶

It is designed to classify commands by assigning a request code and extract the necessary parameters from them. Some pre-established syntax rules are checked during the execution of this function, such as the number of parameters issued by the user and the existence of the mandatory ones within them.

Parameters:

command (str) -- the command issued by the user

Returns:

a tuple made up of 3 elements, from which the first one indicates the success/failure of the parsing operation which was attempted, the second one represents the request code and the third one is a list of the actual parameters of the request. The request code has 4 possible values, which correspond to the 4 basic operations which the user can execute: upload, read, delete file and exit.

Return type:

(bool, int, list[str])

command_parser.upload_validate(params: list[str]) -> (<class 'bool'>, list[str])¶

Validates the upload parameters issued by user in the second part of his query.

Parameters:

params (list[str]) -- the raw parameter string issued by the user

Returns:

the validation tuple made up of the OK code and the actual parameters' list

Return type:

(bool, list[str])

command_parser.validate_command(request_code: int, params: list[str]) -> (<class 'bool'>, list[str])¶

Splits validation into particular cases depending on the command type/request code the user issued. Significance of codes: 0 ~ upload; 1 ~ read; 2 ~ delete; 3 ~ exit.

Parameters:

  • request_code (int) -- the request code deduced according to the above signification

  • params (list[str]) -- the raw parameter string issued by the user; includes specifications such as -n or -p which are meant to be eliminated after parsing

Returns:

the validation tuple made up of the OK code and the actual parameters' list

Return type:

(bool, list[str])

This module serves for reading texts from different file formats. Advanced elements such as images, charts, passwords may cause unusual behaviour to the program.

Reads content of docx files.

file_path (str) -- the absolute/relative path to the target file

Returns:

the content of the file encoded in hexadecimal format (preliminary utf-8 encoding is worth being mentioned as well)

Return type:

str

Returns:

decoding character set suitable for the file

reader.read_data(file_path: str) → str¶

This function aims to read the content of the specified file, taking its extension into consideration as a hint for its formatting type (Windows OS).

Parameters:

file_path (str) -- the absolute/relative path to the target file

Returns:

the content of the file, taking the format into account while encoding to serve the purposes of the application; the content is represented in base16

Return type:

str

Returns:

Return type:

str

This module represents the ambition to implement the Miller-Rabin primality test.

miller_rabin.decompose_number(number: int) -> (<class 'int'>, <class 'int'>)¶

In order to prepare for executing the Miller-Rabin primality test, the number is written as t * pow(2, s), where s is maximized and t is odd.

Parameters:

number (int) -- the number to decompose, on which the Miller-Rabin test is to be performed

Returns:

s and t, the components of the number's decomposition as described

Return type:

(int, int)

miller_rabin.is_prime(number: int) → bool¶

This function tests for the primality of a number using the Miller-Rabin test. The target number is firstly tested against a couple of low primes. The reason behind this resides in the low performance and precision of the Miler-Rabin test if the target number can be factorized using at least one low prime.

Parameters:

number (int) -- the number to be introduced in the primality test

Returns:

True if the number is prime according to the Miller-Rabin test; False, otherwise

Return type:

bool

miller_rabin.miller_rabin_test(number: int) → bool¶

The Miller-Rabin primality test implemented.

Parameters:

number (int) -- the target number to be tested for primality

Returns:

True if the number is prime according to one iteration of the Miller-Rabin test; False, otherwise

Return type:

bool
